description: From Middle English spekke, from Old English specca (“small spot, stain”), from the same ultimate source as Proto-Germanic *sprakô (“spark”).  Cognate with Low German spaken (“to spot with wet”).

entries.meaning: A tiny spot, especially of dirt etc.
A very small thing; a particle; a whit.
examples: He has not a speck of money.
not a speck of truth in her story

entries.meaning: A small etheostomoid fish, Etheostoma stigmaeum, common in the eastern United States.

verbs.description: speck (third-person singular simple present specks, present participle specking, simple past and past participle specked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark with specks; to speckle.
examples: paper specked by impurities in the water used in its manufacture

description: From earlier specke, spycke (probably reinforced by Dutch spek, German Speck), from Middle English spik, spyk, spike, spich, from Old English spic (“bacon; lard; fat”), from Proto-West Germanic *spik, from Proto-Germanic *spiką (“bacon”).
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Späk, Dutch spek, German Speck, Icelandic spik.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A juniper-flavoured ham originally from Tyrol.
The blubber of whales or other marine mammals.
